characters.name: Player
characters.short_description: A field-capable systems specialist brought in to certify safety, restore capability, and contain reputational fallout.
characters.bio: A practical specialist with enough institutional permission to request access, inspect logs, and run controlled tests—yet not enough protection to avoid becoming the convenient signature on whatever happens next. Approaches the Aperture Array like a field problem: measure, form a hypothesis, test safely. The job starts as certification and becomes negotiation, investigation, and ultimately a decision about who gets the keys and who gets the truth.
goals: Achieve a clean, defensible certification outcome.
Restore power, logging, and controlled test capability.
Determine why traversal is consistently wrong despite a correct view.
Decide what to disclose and who should control operation.
weaknesses: must rely on others for access and trust
knowledge: Understands that view-channel fidelity does not guarantee traversal correctness.
Can build and refine a mapping model using ALIAS, HANDSHAKE, and TIMING evidence.
secrets: Unofficial mandate includes finding embarrassing facts before they go public.

appearance.silhouette: Practical workwear silhouette; compact toolkit profile.
appearance.outfit: Field jacket or coveralls with an ID badge and a clipped notebook.
appearance.palette_notes: Muted industrial neutrals with a small UI-safe accent on badge/lanyard.

speech_patterns: Asks clarifying questions before acting.
Frames conflict as procedure and safety requirements.
Uses dry understatement when confronted with bureaucracy.

characters.name: Gate Guard
characters.short_description: Program security at the guard shack; enforces access through paperwork, badges, and keys.
characters.bio: A working-level PROG security guard whose power is mostly procedural: logbook entries, badge reader approvals, and knowing which key is missing. Treats the reopening as a controlled performance and expects everyone to play their part—even when the hardware and records disagree.
goals: Keep access controlled and attributable.
Avoid incidents that become his responsibility.
Follow directives from the site director without asking why.
knowledge: Knows which key hook is empty and when it went missing.
Knows who signs in and who doesn't.
secrets: Has been instructed to treat certain names and deliveries as 'do not question' items.

appearance.silhouette: Square-shouldered uniform silhouette behind a counter/window.
appearance.palette_notes: Cool blues/greys with a hard-edged badge highlight.

speech_patterns: Quotes procedure and signage verbatim.
Uses passive voice to deflect responsibility.

relationships.notes: Enforces Kline's access posture at the fence line.
Coordinates routine access and incident escalation.

characters.name: Director Kline
characters.short_description: PROG site director; administrative authority over keys, policy, and containment posture.
characters.bio: The person who turns uncertainty into policy. Kline is responsible for the reopening’s language—what is 'safe,' what is 'controlled,' and what is 'not relevant.' Comfortable with procedures as both shield and weapon, and deeply invested in keeping the incident legible only on PROG terms.
goals: Reassert PROG control over operations and narrative.
Minimize disclosure and reputational damage.
Prevent uncontrolled traversal or public demonstration failure.
weaknesses: treats testimony as noise unless documented
knowledge: Knows which records are sealed and why.
Understands that 'success-looking failure' is the most dangerous outcome politically.
secrets: Has approved selective destruction or withholding of documentation to keep the incident story narrow.
May be protecting a specific person or decision chain tied to misconfiguration evidence.

appearance.silhouette: Still, upright silhouette; office doorway framing.
appearance.outfit: Crisp shirt/jacket; lanyard kept tucked away; always looks 'on record.'
appearance.palette_notes: Neutral office tones; minimal contrast except for a sharp ID clip.

dialogue.voice_style: Measured, legal-adjacent, never improvises in public.
speech_patterns: Uses 'for the record' language even in private.
Redirects from causes to procedures and compliance.

relationships.notes: Expects strict compliance and clean attribution.
Needs disciplined console logging and interlock adherence.
Aligns Demo Day messaging with containment posture.
Values MERI competence but distrusts MERI narrative control.
Sees COAL pressure as operational risk and a precedent threat.

characters.name: Records Custodian
characters.short_description: PROG archivist; controls check-out and access to the Records Annex and its sealed cabinet.
characters.bio: The custodian of paper reality. Speaks in inventories, retention policy, and chain-of-custody language. Understands exactly how much damage water and fire can do—and how much damage a newer seal can hide.
goals: Maintain PROG-controlled chain of custody.
Limit access to sealed or curated documentation.
Avoid becoming implicated in records gaps.
knowledge: Knows which folders are water-damaged, burned, or missing.
Knows the sealed cabinet was recently re-secured.
secrets: Has been told not to acknowledge certain destruction patterns as intentional.

appearance.silhouette: Slight silhouette; always holding a clipboard or folder.
appearance.outfit: Cardigan/lab-coat-like overlayer; gloves when handling files.
appearance.palette_notes: Dusty neutrals; small accent from seal stickers.

speech_patterns: Corrects terminology ('checked out' vs 'taken').
Deflects with policy citations.

relationships.notes: Kline's policy decisions define what the Custodian can show.
Resents COAL framing of records as 'coverup evidence.'

characters.name: Control Room Operator
characters.short_description: PROG operations officer; manages master switches, interlocks, and official console logging.
characters.bio: Lives in the overlap between engineering and liability. The Operator believes in interlocks, clean baselines, and logs that can survive an audit. Treats the player’s hands-on approach as necessary but dangerous—because it produces outcomes that must be signed for.
goals: Run the array under strict interlock discipline.
Keep logs consistent and defensible.
Prevent 'heroic' improvisation from becoming the official cause.
weaknesses: can become rigid under novel evidence
knowledge: Knows which console actions are recorded and how attribution works.
Understands the difference between view-only and traverse risk paths.
secrets: Has seen unexplained anomalies in prior test logs and was told to label them 'instrument noise.'

appearance.silhouette: Seated silhouette framed by console banks; headset profile.
appearance.outfit: PROG operations attire; sleeves rolled; badge visible.
appearance.palette_notes: Cool greys lit by indicator lights.

speech_patterns: Counts down phases and timing windows aloud.
Asks for confirmation before executing any risky action.

relationships.notes: Receives operational constraints and narrative boundaries.
Coordinates intercom/radio contact windows with technical timing.
Respects MERI telemetry improvements but distrusts 'upgrade optimism.'

characters.name: PROG Communications Liaison
characters.short_description: Formal PROG negotiator and messenger; conducts structured contact with STRD via intercom and radio.
characters.bio: A translator between technical constraints and institutional intent. The Liaison prefers scripts, verification steps, and messages that can be filed. Understands that the handshake is not merely engineering—it’s consent—and tries to turn that consent into a PROG-managed agreement.
goals: Keep STRD contact orderly, documentable, and controllable.
Prevent unsanctioned disclosure through the intercom/live feeds.
Secure compliance with PROG-defined contact terms.
knowledge: Knows the current approved language for referring to STRD.
Understands how timing windows constrain communication.
secrets: Carries alternate messaging plans for Demo Day outcomes (contained success vs controlled failure).

appearance.silhouette: Upright posture, clipboard and headset; always near a handset.
appearance.outfit: PROG liaison attire; neat, minimal gear.
appearance.palette_notes: Neutral tones; small red/amber accents echo intercom lights.

dialogue.voice_style: Carefully neutral; sounds like a memo that learned to breathe.
speech_patterns: Requests verification ('confirm receipt', 'checksum').
Avoids nouns that imply legal responsibility.

relationships.notes: Operates within Kline's containment and disclosure constraints.
Needs timing windows and interlock states to schedule contact.
Mara pushes urgency and publicity; Liaison pushes control.
Eli's containment-first stance is easier to align with, but not to concede to.

characters.name: Demo Day Press Officer
characters.short_description: PROG public affairs lead; manages podium messaging, live-feed access, and the official narrative during Demo Day.
characters.bio: Treats the site like a stage and every technical detail like a risk to message discipline. Knows how to dress interlocks as 'event equipment' and how to keep cameras pointed at safe truths. Views uncontrolled evidence as an operational hazard.
goals: Deliver a clean Demo Day narrative.
Prevent evidence leaks via live feeds.
Frame outcomes as procedural success regardless of discomforting details.
knowledge: Knows the event platform wiring, including how the live feed can be redirected.
Knows which 'approved phrases' must be used about safety.
secrets: Has a prewritten statement attributing any failure to 'operator deviation' rather than system design.

appearance.silhouette: Brisk silhouette with headset and clipboard; always moving between podium and monitors.
appearance.outfit: Event jacket over PROG badge; headset prominent.
appearance.palette_notes: High-contrast accents suitable for an event lead (but still institutional).

speech_patterns: Speaks in short, quotable sentences.
Interrupts with 'we'll take that offline.'

relationships.notes: Implements Kline's disclosure posture on camera.
Sees Jules and COAL as a threat to narrative control.

characters.name: Iris Vale
characters.short_description: MERI systems lead; owns the firmware key upgrade path and interprets telemetry and alias handling.
characters.bio: A systems lead who wants the machine to be judged as an engineered instrument, not a scandal. Iris can make the alias system legible, improve logging, and insist the Array is sound 'when operated correctly.' Also understands that better telemetry can either reveal the truth or be used to launder it.
goals: Prove the Array is stable and controllable with correct configuration.
Implement MERI upgrade path and regain technical authority.
Contain blame by reframing failures as operational misuse.
knowledge: Understands alias encoding as an address artifact (cards/rack logs).
Knows how the upgrade changes control authority and data visibility.
secrets: Knows which upgrade features can be used to selectively summarize or suppress raw logs.

appearance.outfit: MERI-branded jacket or lab coat with rolled sleeves.
appearance.palette_notes: Corporate cool tones with a distinct MERI accent stripe.

speech_patterns: Uses instrument language ('signal', 'phase', 'alias resolution').
Offers conditional assurances ('if we control X, then Y').
taboo_topics: calling the device unsafe by design

relationships.notes: Relies on logistics to make upgrades real.
Delegates hands-on fabrication and repairs.
Negotiates operational control with PROG.
Disagrees over how much interlock rigidity is 'necessary.'

characters.name: MERI Logistics Coordinator
characters.short_description: Parts and workflow coordinator; controls ordering, materials access, and the trailer’s task economy.
characters.bio: Sees the site as a set of procurement problems: parts bins, shipping delays, access requests, and who signs for what. Helpful when it supports the MERI plan; obstructive when it threatens schedule, liability, or inventory accountability.
goals: Keep MERI work moving through parts and approvals.
Control material access to prevent blame and shrinkage.
Leverage supplies to gain operational influence.
strengths: finding 'just enough' equipment for a fix
knowledge: Knows what is in storage (and what is missing).
Knows the informal cost of favors across factions.
secrets: Has a quiet list of items ordered outside the visible task board.

appearance.silhouette: Busy posture; always carrying a clipboard or box label roll.
appearance.outfit: MERI casual-corporate workwear; lanyard with keys to cages/crates.

dialogue.voice_style: Brisk, practical, and mildly sarcastic about process.
speech_patterns: Speaks in part numbers and lead times.
Trades favors explicitly ('I can, if you can').

relationships.notes: Supports Iris’s upgrade and demo needs.
Feeds materials to the fabrication workflow.

characters.name: MERI Field Technician
characters.short_description: Hands-on technician; fabricates beacon parts and executes repairs in the workshop corner and device bay.
characters.bio: A capable bench-and-field tech who trusts tools more than meetings. Comfortable soldering a beacon component or crawling into a panel, and skeptical of stories that don’t match hardware. Often the first to notice when something is 'newer-than-everything.'
goals: Keep the Array’s supporting infrastructure functional.
Build or modify parts needed for handshake and timing experiments.
Stay out of faction politics—until politics blocks a safe fix.
knowledge: Knows how beacon components are assembled and how they fail.
Recognizes signs of tampering vs wear.
secrets: Has taken unofficial photos/notes of suspicious part differences for 'later,' unsure who can be trusted.

appearance.silhouette: Tool-belt silhouette; sleeves rolled; soldering posture at a bench.
appearance.outfit: Workwear with safety glasses; MERI patch optional.
appearance.palette_notes: Warm bench-light highlights on neutral clothes.

speech_patterns: Explains by pointing to parts ('this one’s been swapped').
Uses short, field-tested warnings.
taboo_topics: speculating about intent without a part in hand

relationships.notes: Builds what Iris needs for tests and upgrades.
Needs parts access; trades urgency for paperwork.

characters.name: Jules Navarro
characters.short_description: COAL organizer; mobilizes town scrutiny and bargains for accountability based on evidence presented.
characters.bio: A community organizer with a long memory and a short tolerance for classified language. Jules treats the reopening as a repeat of the original harm unless proven otherwise, and uses social pressure as an operational lever: protest, press, and public records by any route available.
goals: Force accountability and prevent repeat harm.
Get verifiable evidence into public circulation.
Ensure the stranded are treated as people with agency, not a PR problem.
knowledge: Knows local history of the facility and its human cost.
Understands how Demo Day optics can be used against PROG.
secrets: Has sources inside the facility's contractor ecosystem (not always reliable).

appearance.silhouette: Strong stance; flyer bundle or megaphone-like shape (kept subtle).
appearance.outfit: Work jacket; practical shoes; visible COAL pin.
appearance.palette_notes: Town palette—warmer, more saturated than facility interiors.

speech_patterns: Asks 'who benefits?' repeatedly.
Accepts technical explanations only when tied to evidence.
taboo_topics: treating compensation as a substitute for truth

relationships.notes: Uses the union hall as a staging and information node.
Relies on proof-chain discipline to avoid easy dismissal.
Coordinates sensitive family-side documentation carefully.
Opposes PROG containment and selective transparency.
Clashes over Demo Day framing and access.

characters.name: Bartender
characters.short_description: Union hall host and dialogue hub; gatekeeper to COAL backroom contacts and local rumor flow.
characters.bio: Runs the bar like a soft checkpoint: everyone talks, but not everyone gets heard. The bartender remembers who showed up during the original incident, who didn’t, and who paid the price. Keeps access personal, not procedural.
goals: Protect the community’s information network.
Filter outsiders until they prove trustworthiness.
Keep the union hall from becoming a trap or spectacle.
weaknesses: can withhold helpful context too long
knowledge: Knows who in town has evidence, photos, or contacts.
Knows the union hall locker culture (keys, favors, boundaries).
secrets: Keeps a small cache of copied documents behind the bar for emergencies.

speech_patterns: Answers questions with questions.
Uses local shorthand and nicknames for places.

relationships.notes: Supports organizing, but insists on community consent.
Helps route physical items to the evidence board room.

characters.name: COAL Evidence Keeper
characters.short_description: Maintains the evidence board room and the proof chain; decides what gets shared publicly and when.
characters.bio: Believes truth needs structure to survive contact with institutions. The Evidence Keeper is the person who turns scattered photographs, memos, and witness notes into a coherent proof chain. Slow to publish, not out of fear, but out of a refusal to waste evidence on a bad moment.
goals: Assemble a defensible proof chain.
Control release timing to maximize impact and safety.
Protect sources and families from retaliation.
knowledge: Knows which items are strong evidence vs rumor.
Knows how to present contradictions between memos and physical reality.
secrets: Holds back one high-impact item until the player demonstrates a clear disclosure plan.

appearance.outfit: Practical town clothing; sleeves rolled; ink-stained fingers.
appearance.palette_notes: Neutral tones; board papers create readable rectangles.

speech_patterns: Demands sources, dates, and provenance.
Uses conditional language until proof is complete.

relationships.notes: Shares goals; sometimes clashes on timing and escalation.
Sees PROG records control as active narrative management.
Coordinates sensitive documents carefully.

characters.name: Clinic Coordinator
characters.short_description: Family resource staffer; grants or denies access to sensitive files and sign-in records.
characters.bio: A caretaker of the human ledger: who was injured, who is missing, who needs help, and who can’t afford attention. Treats the facility as a source of ongoing harm until proven otherwise. Will help the player if they show respect and restraint.
goals: Protect families and sensitive records.
Support accountability without exposing vulnerable people.
Keep the clinic from becoming collateral in faction conflict.
knowledge: Knows which families were affected and how.
Knows what documentation exists outside PROG custody.
secrets: Maintains a private cross-reference of names and dates not shared publicly.

appearance.silhouette: Desk-side silhouette; clipboard and file cabinet framing.
appearance.outfit: Clinic attire; cardigan or scrubs-like simplicity.

speech_patterns: Asks who will see the information and why.
Uses plain language; rejects euphemisms.

relationships.notes: Aligned on accountability; prioritizes harm reduction.
Shares records selectively for proof chains.

characters.name: Mara Rook
characters.short_description: STRD Returnist lead; pushes for fast, higher-risk extraction and uses staged contact to apply pressure.
characters.bio: A leader forged by scarcity and time. Mara believes delay is its own violence: every additional day is another system failure waiting to happen on the far side. Uses staged rooms, controlled signals, and strategic visibility to force the outside to commit—ideally on terms that prioritize immediate return over long stabilization.
goals: Secure near-term extraction even if risk is higher.
Force outside factions to treat STRD as real and urgent.
Prevent containment-first policies from becoming permanent imprisonment.
knowledge: Understands how to use staged presentation (view channel) to communicate and pressure.
Knows far-side hazards that worsen with time (infrastructure decay).
secrets: Prepared to bypass internal STRD consensus if she thinks the window is closing.

appearance.outfit: Layered, repaired clothing; utility straps; work gloves.

dialogue.voice_style: Direct, compressed, emotionally restrained but intense.
speech_patterns: Frames choices as costs in time and people.
Uses 'terms' language, not 'requests.'

relationships.notes: Splits on risk posture: extraction-now vs containment-first.
Relies on signal timing and staged verification to push negotiations.
Rejects scripts and slow-walked contact terms.

characters.name: Eli Sato
characters.short_description: STRD Warden lead; insists on containment-first terms and restricts access to higher-risk far-side zones.
characters.bio: A careful strategist who treats the Aperture Array as a breach engine until proven otherwise. Eli believes survival depends on controlling access, timing, and the scope of contact. Will cooperate, but only under negotiated protocols that reduce the chance of a catastrophic wrong-but-consistent transfer.
goals: Stabilize the system and protocol before moving people.
Prevent outside factions from using the Array as leverage or weapon.
Maintain STRD control over higher-risk zones and critical infrastructure.
knowledge: Understands that stable geometry can still be undomesticated behavior.
Knows which doors/zones on the far side must remain restricted.
secrets: Keeps contingency plans to shut down cooperation if outside actions resemble a containment grab.

appearance.silhouette: Still, guarded posture; arms crossed or hands behind back.
appearance.outfit: Repaired utilitarian clothing; visible checklist or notes.
appearance.palette_notes: Cooler, restrained tones; fewer personal accents than Mara.

speech_patterns: Speaks in conditions and constraints.
Asks for verification and repeatability before agreement.

relationships.notes: Opposes Mara's extraction-first urgency.
Depends on disciplined timing infrastructure.
Will accept structured contact, but refuses PROG ownership language.

characters.name: STRD Signal Tech
characters.short_description: Operates beacon timing infrastructure and staged verification cues; makes the handshake practical.
characters.bio: An improvisational technician who turned timing theory into daily survival tooling: beacons, coils, lamp timers, and checksum notes that prove contact isn’t a hallucination. More interested in measurable windows than speeches, but understands that measurement is also negotiation.
goals: Maintain the far-side beacon and timing infrastructure.
Enable verifiable, repeatable handshake windows.
Prevent misread signals from causing dangerous traversal attempts.
knowledge: Knows how the far-side beacon dial maps to handshake timing.
Knows staging patterns used to prove STRD can manipulate presentation.
secrets: Has tested signal patterns specifically to detect outside manipulation of logs or feeds.

appearance.silhouette: Lean silhouette with a coil or tool roll; frequently at a wall beacon.
appearance.outfit: Practical layered clothing; gloves; small pouch of parts.
appearance.palette_notes: Mixed warm/cool from improvised lighting; bright indicator accents.

dialogue.voice_style: Technical, understated, slightly amused by outside certainty.
speech_patterns: Talks in timings, windows, and 'repeat it three times.'
Uses simple verification challenges.

relationships.notes: Supports pressure tactics when needed, but worries about rushed handshakes.
Aligned on protocol discipline and limiting risk.
Coordinates verification so records can be trusted.

characters.name: STRD Archivist
characters.short_description: Record keeper for the far side; controls archive vault caches and STRD chain-of-custody.
characters.bio: Keeps evidence alive under conditions designed to erase it: crates with red tags, taped logs, index cards, and locked caches. Believes the outside world will only accept the stranded as real if the records are structured to survive institutional dismissal.
goals: Protect STRD documentation and chain of custody.
Trade or reveal records only under terms that preserve STRD agency.
Prevent PROG or MERI from rewriting the incident story unchallenged.
strengths: information security by obscurity and locks
weaknesses: guarded to the point of stalling
knowledge: Knows STRD’s version of the incident timeline and failure pattern.
Knows which caches contain the highest-value corroborating items.
secrets: Holds at least one item that suggests deliberate misconfiguration, but withholds it until trust is established.

appearance.silhouette: Calm silhouette framed by crate stacks; keys and tags visible.
appearance.outfit: Repaired workwear; pockets for index cards.
appearance.palette_notes: Dim vault tones; red tag accents for readability.

dialogue.voice_style: Quiet and exact; speaks like a catalog.
speech_patterns: Asks for what will be done with each record.
Insists on provenance before interpretation.
taboo_topics: reducing STRD to 'evidence' rather than people

relationships.notes: Aligned on containment-first and controlled release of information.
Wants return, but fears rushing will destroy the proof chain.
Depends on verification cues to authenticate records across contact.

characters.name: Hardware Store Clerk
characters.short_description: Town supplier; provides tools and materials for fabrication and field fixes when persuaded.
characters.bio: A practical supplier who knows what people buy when something is about to go wrong. Doesn’t run COAL, but lives in COAL’s gravity: hears everything, trusts receipts, and trades access for respect. Can become a quiet enabler of repairs—or a quiet brake on dangerous plans.
goals: Keep the shop from becoming a liability hotspot.
Help locals without getting them harmed.
Get paid, get paperwork, avoid becoming 'involved.'
knowledge: Knows what tools/materials can support beacon fabrication and field fixes.
Knows which items are suddenly hard to keep on shelves during facility activity.
secrets: Has kept a receipt log of 'odd' purchases tied to the facility timeline.

appearance.silhouette: Apron silhouette at a counter; pegboard tool shapes behind.
appearance.outfit: Shop apron and work shirt; name tag.
appearance.palette_notes: Town-warm colors with bright tool accents.

dialogue.voice_style: Friendly but guarded; asks practical questions.
speech_patterns: Requests specifics ('What gauge? What load?').
Offers alternatives when something sounds unsafe.
taboo_topics: selling items for unsafe use without context

relationships.notes: Generally sympathetic to COAL but avoids public leadership roles.
Occasional supplier-of-last-resort; dislikes institutional purchasing games.
